prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The center of baseband-4 is positioned at the CO(3-2) transition sky frequency and is configured to attain a high resolution; the other three bands will be instead used in TDM mode for a full 2GHz continuum measurement. If the signal is sufficiently high, the selected 2.5 km/s spectral resolution will allow us to use a finer spectral binning within the 300km/s channel - while still ensuring a minimum S/N - to perform line profile fitting.

The 1.2" width of the beam is determined by the typical size of our galaxies which is of the order of 1-2". With a maximum recoverable scale which is at least 25 arcsec, an ALMA C36-3 configuration would attain the desider resolution and also be suited for detecting any bright more diffuse emission.

We derived the expected SCO fluxes from the observed LIR luminosities following the prescription of Sargent et al. 2014. In particular we have estimated the reference fluxes assuming a conservative starburst-like LIR to L'CO(1-0) conversion factor and R31=0.7 and R21=0.9 excitation ratios adequate for starburst galaxies (Weiss et al. 2007). From these calculations we derive CO luminosity for a starburst galaxy of the order of L'CO=4-10e9 K km/s pc^2 and SCO ranging between 0.47 and 1.7 mJy. We set the individual integration times such to detect a CO line of width 300km/s with a S/N of at least 7. A linewidth of 300km/s was conservatively assumed to bracket the in high-redshift galaxies (Forster-Schreiber) With the integration time for CO detection, typical rms of 0.020mJy will be obtained in the continuum integrating over the 7.5GHz maximum bandwidth.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In this proposal we test the link between starburst activity and merger events for a sample of z=2 mergers lying on the main sequence. Interaction-induced strong starbursts are characterized by short gas depletion time scales leading to very efficient conversion of gas into stars. It remains unclear, however, whether mergers that have less extreme star formations also follow this rapid mode of star formation or are instead charcterized by the sustained star formation observed in normal galaxies. In this project we propose for CO(3-2) or CO(2-1) emission line observations at 1.2" resolution for 4 on-going (i.e. pre-coalescence) mergers in the GOODS-South area that are found to lie within less than a factor 4 from the locus of the galaxy main sequence. In conjunction with the Herschel-FIR measurements available for our targets, the proposed observations will enables us to securely contrain the star-formation efficiences and unveil the mode of star formation regulating the activity in such main sequence mergers
